text: So i decided to take the plunge and start learning two big things over the last week. SQL and Pycharm. Can't say i think much of the former, but the latter is and absolute game changer. Regarding SQL, it takes me eight times longer to load my database up than loading it from pickle. Even longer to save it. The only case i can see this being useful is if I kept the thing open, sending in data to it periodically. At the moment pandas/pkl is so fast i can recreate my entire dataset from file faster than SQL can load. And anything that involves conversion between the two... forget about it :sweat_smile:

text: I think I might be able to skip SQL altogether and go for something like MongoDB. It's looking pretty promising from what i've seen. It could possibly even store ml models and associated dataframes/transformer objects,

elements.text: I think I might be able to skip SQL altogether and go for something like MongoDB. It's looking pretty promising from what i've seen. It could possibly even store ml models and associated dataframes/transformer objects,

text:
Thanks for sharing your findings.

Won't MongoDB be worse than SQL? A well designed SQL database will generally outperform MongoDB.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
Thanks for sharing your findings.

Won't MongoDB be worse than SQL? A well designed SQL database will generally outperform MongoDB.

text: To be honest if you’ve got flat files working with your setup there’s basically no reason to change. Also storing ML models in a database seems kinda pointless to me, how would you use it any different to on disk?

elements.text: To be honest if you’ve got flat files working with your setup there’s basically no reason to change. Also storing ML models in a database seems kinda pointless to me, how would you use it any different to on disk?

text:
Mongo could be worse, I don't have any experience with it so... I'll try a few things, as long as they have a python interface. Pandas own write to SQL library failed to complete at all with my final dataset without it being split up into parts, even then it was problematic (creating ghost entries).
Although the flat files thing is working, it's getting messy- i've got raw, unprocessed data, then cleaned, workable data, then formatted data, then finally transformed data. Trying to keep it all linked with folders and file names seems cursed.

elements.text:
Mongo could be worse, I don't have any experience with it so... I'll try a few things, as long as they have a python interface. Pandas own write to SQL library failed to complete at all with my final dataset without it being split up into parts, even then it was problematic (creating ghost entries).
Although the flat files thing is working, it's getting messy- i've got raw, unprocessed data, then cleaned, workable data, then formatted data, then finally transformed data. Trying to keep it all linked with folders and file names seems cursed.

text: All that said I'm probably going to come back here in a week and say ignore everything i just said, it was a skill issue and i just needed to use sql properly :sweat_smile:
